results.title: Electron microscopy
results.creator_credit: Michael Clarke, Associated Electrical Industries Film Unit and Michael Crossfield
results.brief_description: Explains the principle of the electron microscope and shows its operation and the methods of preparing specimens by ultra-microtome and carbon film cast. Shows examples of the detail of fine structure observed in various materials, and the observation of experiments carried out under the microscope on surface wear and crystal structure of metals.

results.title: Electron arrangement and bonding
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
The purpose of these six episodes is to show the importance of the electron to chemical compunds. Illustrates the development of the atomic model by scientists such as Bohr, Rutherford and Planch, and relates their contributions to an understanding of the function of electrons. Highlights various aspects of energy levels, orbitals, charges, relative mass, bonding and electron configuration. Includes: 1. “Introduction to the players”, 2. “The Rutherford-Bohr atom”, 3. “Electron arrangement”, 4. “How atoms bond”, 5. “Molecular substance and covalent crystals”, 6. “Metals and ionic solids.”

results.title: Electromagnets and their uses
results.brief_description: Shows how electricity can be used to make magnets, and presents various applications of electromagnets. Describes the effects of coiling a wire and adding a core, and demonstrates the effect of current direction on polarity. Suitable for upper primary level.
results.description: Shows how electricity can be used to make magnets, and presents various applications of electromagnets. Describes the effects of coiling a wire and adding a core, and demonstrates the effect of current direction on polarity. Suitable for upper primary level.

results.title: Electromagnetism
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: physics”.
The historical discovery of the magnetic properties of lodestone led to a scientific understanding of Earth’s magnetic field. Six ten minute computer-animated episodes explore this mysterious force from early experiments to the concepts of electromagnetic induction, the motor principle, generators, and transformers. It also looks at fascinating modern theories about the role of the Earth’s magnetic field in the extinction of species and at the ways that animals use it for navigation. The programs include: 1. Earth’s magnetic field 4. The Motor principle 2. Magnetism and electron flow 5. Electromagnetic induction 3. Domain theory 6. Life in the field

results.title: Electromagnetic waves
results.brief_description: Part of the Physical Science Study Committee series. Shows why we believe in the unity of the electro-magnetic radiation spectrum. Experiment shows that the radiation arises from accelerated charge and consists of transverse waves that can be polarised. Interference (Young’s double slit experiment) is shown in four different regions of electromagnetic spectrum: X-ray, visible light, microwave and radiowave.

results.title: Electrolysis
results.creator_credit: McGraw-Hill Films and MGM International Films
results.brief_description: Standard electrolysis equipment is set up and operated to demonstrate the conduction of electricity through a liquid. The electrical connections are made and the process takes place; oxygen and hydrogen ions are formed and the liquid conducts a current of electricity.

results.title: Electrodynamics
results.brief_description: The following fundamental principles of current electricity and electro-magnetism are presented in this film: Galvani’s discovery of current electricity; a magnetic field about a current-carrying wire; the magnetic field of a coil; electromagnets; Rowland’s experiment; magnetic hypothesis; recalescence; induction by a magnet; AC and DC generators; induction by an electric current; and transformers and their function.
results.description: The following fundamental principles of current electricity and electro-magnetism are presented in this film: Galvani’s discovery of current electricity; a magnetic field about a current-carrying wire; the magnetic field of a coil; electromagnets; Rowland’s experiment; magnetic hypothesis; recalescence; induction by a magnet; AC and DC generators; induction by an electric current; and transformers and their function.

results.title: Electrochemistry (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Barrie Whatley, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Teaches the basic concepts of electrochemical cells, starting with the question of how chemical reactions can be used to provide electricity using the displacement of silver from solution by copper

results.title: Electrochemistry
results.creator_credit: Frank A. Hoare, Merton Park and John Durst
results.brief_description: Diagrams and a simple bench experiment demonstrate theory and practice of electro-plating. Industrial applications of electro-chemistry in copper refining, the reduction of alumina to metallic aluminium and the plating and surface treatment of metal parts are illustrated. Deals also with the electro-chemical action in batteries and accumulators.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Frank A. Hoare, Merton Park and John Durst

results.title: Electrochemistry
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontaria
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: chemistry”.
Shows students inside an everyday battery and explains the principles involved. Highlights the processes of electro-chemical reactions, how half-cell potentials can be determined, how electrochemistry is at work in the commercial Leclanche cell and the processes of corrosion and electrolysis. Each episode is ten minutes in duration: 1. The Building blocks of electrochemistry. 2. Electrochemical cells. 3. Designing electrochemical cells. 4. Commercial electrochemical cells. 5. Corrosion and 6. Electroplating.
